information: The federal budget deficit for the fiscal year ending September 30, 2025, is projected to be $2.2 trillion. The Congressional Budget Office (CBO) estimates that a Republican-proposed bill to cut taxes and eliminate certain programs would add an additional $2.4 trillion to the national debt over the next decade. Interest payments on the debt have become one of the largest federal expenses, exceeding defense spending and projected to surpass $1 trillion annually. According to the Treasury Department, net interest expenditure for the first seven months of the 2025 fiscal year totaled $578.7 billion. In 2025, $9.2 trillion of existing U.S. debt is scheduled to mature, with $6.5 trillion of that amount coming due between January and June.

forecast.status_quo_outcome: No — debt remains below $37T by June 27 on the current trajectory
forecast.no_outcome_scenario: Normal monthly borrowing continues, June corporate tax receipts reduce net issuance mid-month, and there is no unusually large late‑June cash-balance rebuild; total public debt stays in the mid–$36T range and does not reach $37T by June 27.
forecast.yes_outcome_scenario: Debt is already very close to $37T (e.g., ≥$36.85T) in early/mid‑June and Treasury executes an unusually large late‑June bill issuance to rebuild the Treasury General Account, pushing total debt over $37T by or just after June 27.
forecast.rationale:
- Status quo and trend: Over the past couple of years, debt has risen roughly $2–3T/year (~$170–250B/month). With only 23 days left, reaching $37T would require the current level to already be very near that mark or an unusually large burst of net issuance in June.
- Timing effects: June often has corporate/estimated tax receipts around mid‑month, which typically reduce net borrowing needs and can temporarily slow the rise in debt. That favors a No outcome by the 27th.
- Research assistant inputs considered: FY2025 deficit projected at ~$2.2T suggests an average monthly run rate around ~$180B. Net interest is large but already part of the deficit math. The $6.5T in maturities Jan–Jun 2025 are mostly rollovers and do not, by themselves, increase total debt. None of these imply a sudden multi‑hundred‑billion spike in late June.
- Why not higher (i.e., why not more likely Yes): With only three weeks left, crossing $37T requires either starting within ~$100–200B of the threshold or engineering an unusually large late‑June cash-balance build. Typical month‑end cash management and mid‑June receipts make a very large late‑June net increase less likely.
- Why not lower (i.e., why not near-zero Yes probability): There is uncertainty about the exact current level. If total debt is already within a couple hundred billion of $37T, a moderate TGA rebuild or heavier‑than‑usual bill issuance could tip it over before June 27. End‑of‑quarter cash management can sometimes be sizable.
- Update triggers:
  • Upward: Daily Debt to the Penny readings show total debt ≥$36.85T by mid‑June; Treasury signals an end‑June TGA rebuild of >$200B; unexpectedly weak receipts or large supplemental outlays.
  • Downward: Debt readings remain ≤$36.6T after mid‑June; stronger‑than‑expected tax inflows; any constraints (formal or practical) limiting net issuance.
Note: The provided FRED link on merchant wholesalers’ inventories/sales ratio is not relevant to debt dynamics and was not used.
